awd_titl_txt: OPP-PRF: Investigating the Effects of Late Holocene Climate Change on Polar Bears
awd_abstract_narration:
Polar bears evolved to thrive in the harsh Arctic environment. Because they depend on sea ice to travel and to hunt seals, past climatic changes that altered sea ice likely affected population size and distribution. This project investigates the effects of climate change – from approximately 5000 years ago to the present – on polar bears in the Bering Sea region. Polar bear remains have been identified from a 4700-year-old archaeological site on Unalaska Island, Alaska. These remains are approximately 200 miles south of where polar bears have been found in the recent past. By studying these remains, and comparing them to modern-day specimens, this research will advance understanding of the effects of historic climate cooling and present-day climate warming on polar bears. The presence of polar bear remains also has implications for the Native Unangan people. To explore the relationship between Unangan ancestors and polar bears, this project will provide training and mentorship to students and enhance the professional development of an early career Arctic scientist. Results from this study will be shared with the community in Dutch Harbor, Alaska, and through conference presentations and peer-reviewed articles.

This project tests the hypothesis that late Holocene climate change resulted in demographic, genomic, and epigenomic changes in Bering Sea polar bears. The PI uses a multidisciplinary approach, combining zooarchaeological, paleogenomic and paleoepigenetic data from Neoglacial bear remains excavated from an archaeological site on Unalaska Island. First, morphometric and genomic DNA sequence data will be used to confirm that the remains are from polar bears and to determine the number of individuals represented in the assemblage. Then, genomic and epigenomic data from the Unalaskan bears will be compared to data from modern-day Bering Sea polar bears and brown bears from the Alaska Peninsula to determine 1) if polar bears and brown bears interbred in the Neoglacial Period, and 2) to assess demographic and adaptive responses of polar bear populations to Neoglacial cooling and present-day climate warming.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The archaeological record offers the opportunity to infer the effects of regional climatic shifts on species distributions and human-animal interactions. In Alaska’s temperate Aleutian Islands, the archaeological record suggests that the Neoglacial climate phase (ca. 4700 - 2500 radiocarbon years before present) was significantly colder and the region likely supported sea ice and ice-dependent animals. Previous analyses identified polar bear remains in Unalaska Bay, more than 300 km south of the farthest southern extent of polar bears in the historical record. Although the presence of polar bears has been used to infer the local presence of sea ice and polar bear range expansion, morphological similarities between brown and polar bears make it difficult to distinguish the two species using external characters alone. The primary objective of this research project was to use zooarchaeological, genomic, and epigenomic data to study archaeofaunal material identified as bear from archaeological contexts in Unalaska, to ultimately understand how Neoglacial climate change impacted bear population dynamics and bear-human relationships in the eastern Aleutian Islands. 

First, this project used zooarchaeological methods to characterize bear remains from two archaeological sites in Unalaska: Margaret Bay (n = 33) and Amaknak Bridge (n = 6). We collected digital photographs, produced three dimensional models, and collected morphometric data from all elements, as well as comparative morphometric data from available post-cranial museum specimens. Through PCA, external characters, aging analysis, and examination of bone modification, we made several inferences. First, the assemblage at Margaret Bay includes at least five individuals of different age classes from young cubs to adults, and both brown and polar bears are represented, while the material at Amaknak Bridge represents at least one individual, though morphometric analysis could not determine species. Anthropogenic modifications were identified on 10 elements and suggest that the bears were skinned, disarticulated, and processed for meat. Signs of butchery and the presence of very young cubs suggests that the bears were available and hunted locally. This, in turn, suggests that local sea ice facilitated both the presence of polar bears from the north and brown bears from Unimak Island to the east. The data from these analyses are archived at the Arctic Data Center (https://doi.org/10.18739/A25T3G219) and this study has been published (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-025-88996-0). 

Next, we collected subsamples from all 39 elements for biomolecular analyses. We obtained radiocarbon dates and bulk stable isotope data (15N and 13C) for 12 samples from Margaret Bay and Amaknak Bridge. These data pushed back the previously inferred dates for the two sites; the Margaret Bay elements are from ca. 5,500 years before present, implying that the onset of the Neoglacial was earlier than previously thought. The Amaknak Bridge elements are from ca. 2,800 years before present. Stable isotope data suggest the presence of both polar bears and brown bears at Margaret Bay, consistent with the zooarchaeological analysis, while Amaknak Bridge included only brown bears. 

We then prepared genomic DNA libraries and used whole genome enrichment methods to increase the proportion of bear DNA in all samples. Our preliminary genetic analyses indicate that the Margaret Bay assemblage includes two polar bear elements and 31 brown bear elements, while all six elements from Amaknak Bridge are brown bear. Genomic and epigenomic data are currently being analyzed and prepared for publication and will be available through the sequence read archive.    

The presence of bears in Unalaska at two time points separated by almost 3,000 years indicates that Unangax̂ ancestors confronted and hunted dangerous, novel predator species that no longer occur on the island. Whether people harvested the animals in defense, for skins or meat, or for social reasons, the remains suggest an unusual ecological relationship developed during the Neoglacial phase.

This project has significantly expanded our understanding of local environmental conditions and human-bear relationships in the eastern Aleutian Islands during the Neoglacial climate phase.

This project provided training and expanded the collaborative networks of the principal investigator. Through mentorship by the principal investigator, it also provided research experience and training to undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Oklahoma in the fields of zooarchaeology, morphometrics, and ancient genetic laboratory and bioinformatics analyses. It also contributed to professional development of the PI and students via attendance and presentation at scientific conferences, travel to museum collections, and pedagogical training in the presentation of scientific results to children and lay audiences. The results of this work were also presented to the community of Unalaska through a public lecture at the Museum of the Aleutinas. Finally, the project produced lesson plans that were taught to children attending Unangan culture camp in Unalaska and students participating in YES Oklahoma, a statewide program that introduces K-12 students to scientific research. These plans are available on the Thingiverse website (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5476596).
